Description: Acne is a skin condition that occurs when hair follicles become plugged with oil and dead skin cells. It causes whiteheads, blackheads, or pimples. Acne is most common among teenagers, though it affects people of all ages.
Diet: ['Low glycemic foods', 'Zinc-rich foods', 'Omega-3 fatty acids', 'Probiotics', 'Green vegetables']
Workout: Regular exercise, Shower after sweating, Stay hydrated, Stress-reducing activities like yoga

Description: Carcinoma is a type of cancer that starts in cells that make up the skin or tissue lining organs. Skin carcinomas include basal cell and squamous cell carcinomas. Early detection and treatment is crucial.
Workout: Light exercise as tolerated, Avoid sun during peak hours, Indoor activities recommended, Follow oncologist guidelines

Description: Eczema (atopic dermatitis) is a condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's common in children but can occur at any age. Eczema is chronic and tends to flare periodically. It may be accompanied by asthma or hay fever.
Diet: ['Anti-inflammatory foods', 'Omega-3 rich fish', 'Probiotics', 'Fruits and vegetables', 'Avoid dairy if trigger']
Workout: Regular gentle exercise, Swimming in chlorine-free pools, Avoid overheating, Shower after sweating

Description: Keratosis refers to skin growths caused by keratin buildup. Actinic keratosis is precancerous from sun damage, while seborrheic keratosis is benign. Regular monitoring is important for actinic types.
Diet: ['Antioxidant-rich foods', 'Vitamin C foods', 'Beta-carotene', 'Green leafy vegetables', 'Stay hydrated']
Workout: Indoor exercises preferred, Avoid prolonged sun exposure, Use sunscreen before outdoor activities, Stay active safely

Description: Milia are small, white bumps that appear on the skin, typically on the face. They occur when keratin becomes trapped beneath the surface of the skin. Milia are harmless and often disappear on their own.
Diet: ['Light healthy diet', 'Adequate hydration', 'Vitamin A foods', 'Avoid heavy oily foods']
Workout: Regular exercise, Good skincare routine, Stay hydrated, Normal daily activities

Description: Rosacea is a common skin condition that causes redness and visible blood vessels in your face. It may also produce small, red, pus-filled bumps. Signs and symptoms may flare up for weeks to months and then go away.
Diet: ['Anti-inflammatory foods', 'Omega-3 fatty acids', 'Avoid spicy foods', 'Avoid alcohol', 'Cooling foods']
Workout: Moderate exercise, Avoid overheating, Exercise in cool environments, Stay hydrated during activity

Description: Actinic keratosis is a rough, scaly patch on your skin that develops from years of exposure to the sun. It's most commonly found on your face, lips, ears, hands, forearms, scalp or neck. Also known as solar keratosis, it is potentially precancerous.
Workout: Avoid prolonged sun exposure, Stay hydrated, Indoor exercises preferred, Use sunscreen before outdoor activities

Description: Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that begins in the basal cells. It often appears as a slightly transparent bump on the sun-exposed skin, though it can take other forms. BCC is caused by long-term exposure to ultraviolet radiation.
Workout: Light exercise as tolerated, Avoid sun during peak hours, Indoor activities, Post-surgery: Follow doctor's activity restrictions

Description: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin is a common form of skin cancer that develops in the squamous cells that make up the middle and outer layers of the skin. SCC is usually not life-threatening, though it can be aggressive.
Workout: Gentle exercise, Avoid direct sunlight, Stress reduction activities, Follow medical team guidelines

Description: Melanoma is the most serious type of skin cancer. It develops in the cells (melanocytes) that produce melanin. Melanoma can form anywhere on your skin, but it most often develops in areas that have had exposure to the sun. Early detection is critical.
Diet: ['Immune-boosting foods', 'Vitamin D supplements', 'Mediterranean diet', 'Lean proteins', 'Colorful fruits and vegetables']
Workout: Follow oncologist recommendations, Light activity as tolerated, Stress management, Avoid sun completely during treatment

Description: Dermatofibroma is a common benign (noncancerous) skin growth. These small, hard bumps most often develop on the lower legs. They're harmless and usually don't cause any symptoms, though they may be itchy or tender.
Medications: ['Usually none required', 'Cryotherapy if bothersome', 'Surgical removal if desired']
Workout: Normal activities, No restrictions, Regular exercise, Avoid trauma to affected area

Description: A nevus (mole) is a common benign growth on the skin. Most moles are harmless, but they should be monitored for changes. Changes in size, shape, or color could indicate melanoma development. Regular self-examinations are important.
Workout: Regular exercise, Sun protection during outdoor activities, Normal daily activities, Self-skin examination monthly

Description: Pigmented benign keratosis, also known as seborrheic keratosis, is a noncancerous skin growth. These growths are common in older adults and appear as brown, black, or tan growths. They're harmless but can be removed for cosmetic reasons.
Diet: ['Skin-healthy foods', 'Vitamins A and E', 'Hydrating foods', 'Omega-3 fatty acids']
Workout: Regular exercise, Adequate hydration, Stress reduction, Normal daily activities

Description: Seborrheic keratosis is one of the most common noncancerous skin growths in older adults. They usually appear as brown, black, or light tan growths. While harmless, they can be numerous and may be removed for cosmetic reasons or if irritated.
Workout: Normal physical activity, No restrictions, Regular exercise routine, Avoid friction on lesions

Description: Vascular lesions are abnormalities of the blood vessels. Common types include hemangiomas, port-wine stains, and spider veins. Most are benign and may appear at birth or develop over time. Treatment depends on type and location.
Workout: Light to moderate exercise, Activities that promote circulation, Avoid high-impact activities if bleeding risk, Leg elevation if needed

Description: Benign keratosis refers to noncancerous skin growths. These include seborrheic keratoses and other harmless skin lesions. They're very common in adults and typically don't require treatment unless they're bothersome or for cosmetic reasons.
Workout: Regular exercise, Normal activities, Adequate rest, Stress management

Description: Melanocytic nevus (common mole) is a benign tumor composed of melanocytes. Most people have 10-40 moles. While usually harmless, they should be monitored using the ABCDE rule: Asymmetry, Border, Color, Diameter, Evolution.
Medications: ['Usually none required', 'Sunscreen SPF 30+', 'Surgical excision if atypical']
Workout: Regular outdoor exercise with sun protection, Self-skin checks monthly, Healthy lifestyle, Avoid peak sun hours

Description: Actinic keratoses (plural) are multiple rough, scaly patches caused by sun damage. They appear on sun-exposed areas and are considered precancerous. About 5-10% may develop into squamous cell carcinoma if left untreated.
Workout: Indoor exercises, Sun avoidance 10am-4pm, Protective clothing outdoors, Stay active safely

Description: Vascular lesions (plural) refer to multiple abnormalities of blood vessels on the skin. These can include cherry angiomas, spider veins, or hemangiomas. Most are benign but may be treated for cosmetic reasons.
Workout: Moderate exercise, Promote good circulation, Avoid excessive heat, Leg elevation if varicose
